update.description:
This PR introduces an `ign-physics-sdf` component which provides features for having a physics plugin construct simulation objects from an SDF data representation.

This also begins the development of an official `ign-physics-dartsim` plugin \(the other PRs that use dartsim were just meant for proofs-of-concept\).

Note that the new features require dartsim version 6 \(I’m specifically testing on 6.7\) and [this branch of ign-math](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/256).
update.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

content.raw: I think we could modularize this process a bit, so that we have one bit of shared code that any physics plugin could use that resolves a URI and uses `ignition::common::MeshLoader` to load an `ignition::common::Mesh`, and then each physics plugin can just translate from `ignition::common::Mesh` to its own native format.
content.html: I think we could modularize this process a bit, so that we have one bit of shared code that any physics plugin could use that resolves a URI and uses ignition::common::MeshLoader to load an ignition::common::Mesh, and then each physics plugin can just translate from ignition::common::Mesh to its own native format.

pull_request.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

content.raw:
Yep, exactly!

This is the method through which plugin developers could provide custom features that are unique to their own plugins.

Plugin developers can export headers that define the interfaces of the features, and then plugin users can depend on those headers and request those features when they go to load an engine.

Note that all the other headers involved in the implementation of the `dartsim-plugin` library are kept in `src/` and never exported. That’s because those headers do not define feature APIs and are not meant to be exposed to end-users. They are only used to make the implementation cleaner and compilation faster \(instead of stuffing the entire plugin implementation into a single translation unit\).
content.html:
Yep, exactly!

This is the method through which plugin developers could provide custom features that are unique to their own plugins.

Plugin developers can export headers that define the interfaces of the features, and then plugin users can depend on those headers and request those features when they go to load an engine.

Note that all the other headers involved in the implementation of the dartsim-plugin library are kept in src/ and never exported. That’s because those headers do not define feature APIs and are not meant to be exposed to end-users. They are only used to make the implementation cleaner and compilation faster (instead of stuffing the entire plugin implementation into a single translation unit).

pull_request.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

content.raw:
Yeah, I’m doing that intentionally to help sniff out bugs.

I believe if I've designed the feature system correctly and implemented the plugin correctly, it should never throw in any of these `at(~)` calls. So if it does throw, then I’m making some faulty assumption or left a bug in the code somewhere.

I actually plan on totally redoing the design of the entity management within the plugin once we've had some time to break in this code and give the feature system an endurance test. If we can confirm that the feature system design is air-tight, then we can replace these maps with `std::vector<void*>` containers and use static\_casts to manage everything. That would be a maximally efficient and maximally performant plugin wrapper, which could probably be generalized to other physics engines very easily.
content.html:
Yeah, I’m doing that intentionally to help sniff out bugs.

I believe if I've designed the feature system correctly and implemented the plugin correctly, it should never throw in any of these at(~) calls. So if it does throw, then I’m making some faulty assumption or left a bug in the code somewhere.

I actually plan on totally redoing the design of the entity management within the plugin once we've had some time to break in this code and give the feature system an endurance test. If we can confirm that the feature system design is air-tight, then we can replace these maps with std::vector<void*> containers and use static_casts to manage everything. That would be a maximally efficient and maximally performant plugin wrapper, which could probably be generalized to other physics engines very easily.

pull_request.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data

content.raw:
Since `tf` is now in World frame,  I don’t think the second argument is not needed here. Otherwise, the transformation from parent to child is applied twice. That’s what happened when I loaded an sdf with the following poses

```xml
...
<model name="sphere">
  <pose>0 0 10 0 0 0</pose>
  <link name="sphere_link">
    <pose>0.0 0.0 0.0 0 0 0</pose>
...
```

After loading, the z position of `sphere_link` is 20 instead of 10. Removing the second argument fixes it for me.
content.html:
Since tf is now in World frame, I don’t think the second argument is not needed here. Otherwise, the transformation from parent to child is applied twice. That’s what happened when I loaded an sdf with the following poses

...
<model name="sphere">
  <pose>0 0 10 0 0 0</pose>
  <link name="sphere_link">
    <pose>0.0 0.0 0.0 0 0 0</pose>
...

After loading, the z position of sphere_link is 20 instead of 10. Removing the second argument fixes it for me.

content.raw:
This PR now includes the ability to load collision and visual data from an SDF.

Note that this branch currently depends on these two SDF PRs:

* [~~https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/453/~~](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/453)
* [~~https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/452/~~](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/452)

Note that this branch currently depends on these two SDF PRs:

update.description:
This PR introduces an `ign-physics-sdf` component which provides features for having a physics plugin construct simulation objects from an SDF data representation.

This also begins the development of an official `ign-physics-dartsim` plugin \(the other PRs that use dartsim were just meant for proofs-of-concept\).

Note that the new features require dartsim version 6 \(I’m specifically testing on 6.7\) and [this branch of ign-math](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/256).
update.title: [WIP] Features for constructing objects from SDF data

pull_request.title: Feature System Part 6: Features for constructing objects from SDF data
